entry.title: From Chaos to Clarity: Transform Faster with SAP Cloud ALM
entry.content:
I recommend to access our Transforming for Success with SAP Cloud ALM learning journey.

Learning outcome
After completing this learning journey, you will be able to:

  • Explain the integrated LeanIX-Signavio-Cloud ALM toolchain via a reusable three-sprint case study.
  • Apply Cloud ALM to reduce costs, accelerate agile project delivery, and optimize operations post go-live for continuous improvement. Align Cloud ALM with SAP Activate and RISE; maintain Clean Core and use the RISE Methodology Dashboard.
  • Plan the move from Solution Manager to Cloud ALM as the operational backbone for RISE.
Goals
  • Get started with SAP: Building the basics
  • Develop your expertise: Skill deepening learning
  • Excel in your expertise: Advanced specialization learning
 
Please post you question related to the digital learning Journey in the Q&A area. 

Our SAP Learning Experts will get back to you as soon as possible! 
We are here to support you.


I appreciate your feedback and we will make sure to continue sharing interesting topics.

Kind regards, Lian

entry.title: Re: Settlement Error in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition...
entry.content:
Hi

You can see the Source structure configuration Central Business Configuration(CBC) in 

Accounting-->Overhead costs --> Overhead Cost Processes --> Period-End Closing -->Create Source Structure

You select your Source Structure YS and Click on Assignment on Left Side Pane

System will show the list of Assignments as below

Now you select  relevant Assignment (100 or 200 in my test system) please check in your system if you have different Assignment than 100 or 200). Select the ASsignment and click on Source. There you assign the GL account.

If there is a Group defined for the source, check in the group if the GL account is mentioned in the Group. For this go to Fiori App Edit Cost Element Group- check your account is listed, if not give your GL account and save, This should resolve your issue of missing GL account in Source Structure in public cloud.

entry.title: Preparing an SAP SuccessFactors Recruiting Instance: From Learning the Basics to Consultant Practice
entry.content:
Introduction

When starting with SAP SuccessFactors Recruiting, topics like Provisioning, Admin Center, and permissions can feel overwhelming â€” especially for beginners. However, these early steps are the foundation of every successful Recruiting implementation.

In this blog, I walk through instance preparation and Admin Center setup in a way that is:

  • Beginnerâ€‘friendly for those new to Recruiting

  • Practical and consultantâ€‘oriented for implementation scenarios

I also share tips and lessons learned from my SAP Young Professional Program (YPP) journey, bridging learning content with real project thinking.

 

1. Instance Preparation: Understanding the Basics (and Why They Matter)

Beginner view: Instance preparation ensures that:

  • Recruiting is technically enabled

  • Administrators can access configuration tools

  • The system is ready to support hiring processes

Consultant view:

  • Verify Recruiting Management is activated in Provisioning

  • Confirm administrator access and permissions

  • Review company and recruitingâ€‘specific settings

  • Align configuration with project scope and client requirements

Consultant Tip: Document Provisioning changes in a shared configuration workbook. SAP promotes documentation as a best practice to avoid confusion and rework.

Common Pitfall: Skipping permission validation can prevent Recruiting options from appearing in Admin Center, delaying configuration and testing.

2. Admin Center: Where Recruiting Comes to Life

Beginner perspective: Admin Center is the place where you:

  • Control who can do what

  • Enable Recruiting features

  • Manage workflows and templates

Consultant perspective: Admin Center acts as the control hub for:

  • Recruiting feature switches

  • Roleâ€‘Based Permissions (RBP)

  • Route maps for job requisition approvals

  • Supporting objects like picklists and rating scales

Client Insight: Clients respond better when consultants explain why certain permissions or workflows are required, not just how to configure them. This helps business users understand Recruiting as part of a larger HCM ecosystem, especially when integrated with modules like Employee Central.

 

3. Route Maps: Governing the Job Requisition Process

In simple terms: Route maps control:

  • Who creates a requisition

  • Who approves it

  • How feedback and revisions are handled

Consultant focus:

  • Keep workflows simple and roleâ€‘based

  • Avoid unsupported features (like signature steps)

  • Explain limitations to clients early to manage expectations

Clear governance prevents redesign and frustration later in the project.

4. Permissions: The Backbone of Recruiting Access

Why this matters for beginners: Without the right permissions:

  • Recruiters may not see requisitions

  • Employees may not access the Careers tab

  • Interviewers may not complete assessments correctly

Consultant focus:

  • Validate administrator, recruiter, and employee roles

  • Ensure background and employee data permissions support Recruiting features

  • Test permissions by logging in with different user roles

Note: SAP emphasizes that permission changes require reâ€‘login to take effect â€” a detail often overlooked during testing.

 

5. Building a Consultant Toolkit (Lessons from SAP YPP)

From my SAP YPP journey, I learned that successful implementations rely on structure, not memory.

Helpful tools include:

  • Checklists for each Recruiting template

  • Comparison tables for design decisions

  • Simple diagrams to explain workflows to business stakeholders

These tools improve workshop efficiency, reduce misunderstandings, and build trust with clients.

 

Conclusion

Instance preparation and Admin Center setup may seem basic at first glance, but they are critical milestones in SAP SuccessFactors Recruiting implementations. When consultants combine clear documentation, correct permissions, and clientâ€‘focused explanations, they create a strong foundation for everything that follows.

ðŸ‘‰In my next blog, Iâ€™ll move into Enabling the Standard Job Requisition, a key step in designing effective Recruiting workflows.

entry.title: Chart of Account - YCOA - S/4 Hana Public Cloud
entry.content:
Introduction to Chart of Account

Mostly FI consultants find this activity as a challenge while working on public cloud for the first time. 

Chart of Account Upload

SAP Public Cloud has provided two pre configured chart of accounts ; YCOA and YIKR. YIKR is the alternative COA of YCOA. No FI consultant can create any other COA. They will have to follow YCOA as nomenclature and can edit the description as per the client's name. 
There are approximately 750+ GLs that form YCOA  standard best practices. Now the greatest challenge arises that what should a FI Consultant do in this situation?
Remember. you are a modern FI consultant, you do not belong to stone age, that you would start creating  500+ GLs manually. 

                                                                                SMART APPROACH 

Cut the tree with an electric saw in smart way rather than using an axe with manual power
MM and SD majorly would require GL assignments in their respective areas. In SAP Cloud, standard GLs are already preconfigured in their areas for say in the traditional Tcodes, OBYC and VKOA. Conduct an integrated meeting with them and tell them how it works so that they won't end up putting wrong GLs. They would suggest you to let them use the wrong GLs. block SAP all GLs, etc, you should use your mind tactfully. They are primary module consultants who will think only in their area whereas FI consultant has a wide horizon to think and work. 
Go to an application "Renumber G/L Accounts", download the mapping and description uploaders. For example, you want to work on assets area, select the provided Asset GLs and infront of them mention your GL numbers (to-be). Fill out the account group and other columns. Upload the file. You will identify your GLs and Cloud GLs by the account group name and the last digit of GL number. SAP GLs end with 0 so do not create your GL with 0 at end, otherwise it will give you error during the upload. 

Provided GL                       

Mapped ID   

Delivered Description Account TypeAccount Group
1000000011000001LandXZOFA

To update the description, first let SAP map the GLs, after which on next uploader you can add your desirable descriptions. Check and then release the mapping to the administrator. Basis consultant would convert the numbers and your working would be saved in the TR automatically. 
There were 750+ GLs, the count would still remain the same. You can now copy your GLs within the same account group after which GL number would increase.

Configurable GLs would be replaced after the mapping, so that no consultant would have to assign the GLs themselves. 

For example, check the pre configured SD Automatic Account Determination, take those GLs and map your GLs infront of them. Likewise, do the rest for all modules. The SAP delivered GL would disappear after the mapping. 

Block/Unblock GLs

If you will block/unblock a GL and TR is moved onto QAS, the blocked GL would also move. If you want not to take some GLs on QAS, then mark it is Not Used in implementation status. 

Changes in GLs can be catered via Mass. Manage GL account Master Data and Manage Operating G/L Account would help a lot in this case. You will have to handle the attributes working very carefully. Two persons at a time cannot work on the apps, it will lock the GL.

COA is TR based so that all 3 servers are synced together. If basis consultant is not available on time then there is a magical app Sychronise GL account master data which will let you work independently. 

Conclusion

Hence, there is no need to create GLs, rather pick the existing provided GLs, match it with your to-be GLs, map it, check it, upload it and import it QAS and PRD. Before import, the implementation status of all GLs should be productive, otherwise they won't be imported. 
The refined your COA would be, the refined your financial statements be. 
SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Finance  FIN (Finance)

entry.title: Authorisations of Business Partners Roles
entry.content:
We are struggling with the authorizations of Business Partners.

 

Our process:

  1. Creation of a business partner by finance FLN00 or CLU00 by the finance department
  2. Extend the supplier or customer BP data by the business, with multiple addresses, contacts, etc..

 

When using the Manage Supplier Master Data App, we  like to extend the supplier BP data with the role FLN01, so the supplier contains both roles FLN00 (set up/ maintained by Finance department) and FLN01 (maintained by Business). But this is not working. Without  authorizations for the role 000000, we are not able to extend a supplier. NO data can be extended, like contacts.

With the 000000 role users can change with the supplier/ customer  master data app also change financial data like bank accounts etc.. They are not allowed to do this. In our governance only people from finance department are allowed to maintain this data.

 

Can  you advise us how we can use the supplier and customer master data apps without giving the role 000000 in te authorization?

entry.title: Future-Proofing SAP AMS: A Strategic Framework for 2025 & Beyond
entry.content:
Future-Proofing SAP AMS: A Strategic Framework for 2025 & Beyond

Introduction

Over the last several years, I have been involved in multiple SAP AMS transitions following S/4HANA go-lives across different customer environments. While each program had its own complexity, one pattern consistently stood out: once the project teams exited, AMS struggled to keep pace with the new operational reality of S/4HANA and cloud-based landscapes.

In this blog, I am sharing what I have personally observed while leading SAP Basis and AMS delivery teams, why traditional AMS models struggle after S/4HANA go-live, and what has worked in practice to build a more future-ready SAP AMS operating model.

What I Observed When AMS Remained Reactive After S/4HANA Go-Live

In several programs I supported, AMS teams were structured around a traditional incident-driven model. This approach worked reasonably well in ECC environments, but in S/4HANA landscapes it quickly became unsustainable. Incident volumes increased, resolution cycles became longer, and teams spent most of their time reacting instead of stabilizing.

What I learned is that S/4HANA environments demand predictive operations, not reactive support. Teams that introduced proactive monitoring, early alerts, and preventive maintenance were able to reduce disruptions significantly. Where AMS remained reactive, instability persisted even months after go-live.

Why Automation Became Non-Negotiable in the AMS Programs I Managed

In the early phases of AMS onboarding, many operational tasks were still handled manually-user administration, system checks, transport validations, and log reviews. This consumed a large portion of the teamâ€™s capacity and left little time for root cause analysis or improvement initiatives.

Across the AMS programs I led, stability improved only after automation was treated as a foundation rather than an enhancement. Introducing automation across L1, L2, and L3 support reduced repetitive effort and improved consistency. More importantly, it allowed teams to shift focus from firefighting to continuous improvement and operational readiness.

Lessons Learned Managing AMS in Hybrid and Cloud Landscapes

As customers moved to hybrid and cloud-based SAP landscapes, AMS complexity increased noticeably. Issues were no longer limited to the SAP application layer but often involved hyperscaler platforms, network dependencies, security controls, and shared responsibility boundaries.

In these environments, AMS teams that lacked cloud operating maturity struggled with escalations and ownership clarity. What worked better was aligning AMS processes with cloud-native operations-integrating SAP Cloud ALM, using hyperscaler monitoring tools, and establishing clear governance for cost, capacity, and security. This alignment reduced friction between teams and improved overall predictability.

Applying SAP Activate Principles Beyond Implementation

While SAP Activate is widely used during implementation, I have seen real benefits when its principles are extended into AMS operations. In several engagements, AMS teams adopted fit-to-standard thinking, sprint-based enhancements, and controlled deployment cycles inspired by Activate.

This helped bring structure and transparency to postâ€“go-live operations. Continuous testing automation, clearer documentation practices, and predictable release cycles made AMS more resilient and easier to manage, especially in fast-changing environments.

Moving Beyond SLA-Driven AMS Metrics

One recurring challenge I observed was the disconnect between AMS performance reports and business perception. AMS teams met SLAs, yet business stakeholders remained dissatisfied due to recurring disruptions during critical cycles.

The programs that performed better shifted focus from SLA-only metrics to business-oriented outcomes. Measuring system stability during month-end, process performance, reduction in disruptions, and user productivity provided a more accurate view of AMS effectiveness. This change also improved conversations with business stakeholders and built greater trust.

Building Resilience Into Everyday AMS Operations

With increasing cyber risks and compliance requirements, resilience became a key focus area in AMS delivery. In practice, this meant embedding disaster recovery readiness, high availability validations, security monitoring, and access reviews into regular operations rather than treating them as separate activities.

In the environments I worked with, automating parts of DR testing and security checks helped teams stay prepared without adding excessive manual effort. This approach significantly improved confidence during audits and critical business periods.

How AMS Roles Are Evolving in Practice

Another important shift I observed is the evolution of AMS skill requirements. Successful AMS teams today are no longer purely technical or functional. They combine SAP Basis knowledge with cloud, automation, security, and strong process understanding.

Teams that invested in cross-skilling especially in automation and observability, were better equipped to manage modern SAP landscapes. This shift also improved team engagement, as engineers moved from repetitive tasks to more value-driven work.

Key Takeaways

  • From my experience, reactive AMS models struggle to support modern S/4HANA landscapes
  • Automation must be treated as a foundation, not an optional improvement
  • Cloud-ready operating models are essential for hybrid and hyperscaler environments
  • Business-aligned metrics provide a more accurate measure of AMS success
  • Future-ready AMS teams require cross-skilled, automation-enabled resources

Conclusion

Based on my experience leading SAP AMS and Basis delivery teams, SAP AMS does not struggle because S/4HANA is unstable. It struggles when operating models fail to evolve with the platform. Organizations that design AMS around predictive operations, automation, cloud readiness, and business outcomes achieve faster stabilisation and stronger business confidence.

My key takeaway is simple: future-proofing SAP AMS is not about adding more processes or tools, but about applying practical experience, accountability, and continuous learning to how support is delivered.

Letâ€™s Discuss

How has your SAP AMS model evolved after S/4HANA go-live? What changes made the biggest difference in improving stability and trust?

I look forward to learning from your experiences.

entry.title: Replicating DMS Documents via Web Services in MDG Scenarios
entry.content:
Content

  • Content
  • 1. Introduction
  • 2. Scenario and Feasible Option
  • 3. Technical Implementation
  • 3.a Architecture Overview
  • 3.b Service Activation and Connection Setup
  • Service Activation
  • SM59 HTTP Destinations
  • 3.c Class Structure
  • 3.d Read Document Links
  • 3.e Download Files via OData
  • CSRF Token Handling
  • Retrieving Attachment Metadata
  • Downloading Binary Content
  • 3.f Create Document in Target System
  • DIR Creation
  • Object Link Creation
  • File Upload
  • 3.g Hook into MDG Outbound Processing
  • 4. Conclusion

 

1. Introduction

In SAP MDG scenarios, master data is governed centrally and replicated to connected systems using web services via the Data Replication Framework (DRF). For Business Partner data, this covers core attributes such as general data, roles, addresses, and bank details.

In many implementations, suppliers and customers have documents attached using SAP Document Management System (DMS). These documents are stored as Document Info Records (DIR) and linked to business objects via table DRAD. During Business Partner replication, document references are transferred as part of the message structure.

However, the content of the original files is not transferred. When source and target systems use different content servers, this results in document links in the target system that point to files users cannot access. Standard options such as DOCMAS IDocs are not web serviceâ€“based and are not integrated with DRF, and SAP does not provide a standard solution for transferring file content in such scenarios.

This blog presents a custom approach that uses standard OData APIs to download document content from the source system and recreate Document Info Records with attachments in the target system, integrated into the MDG outbound replication process.

Note: This solution targets on-premise SAP environments. SAP S/4HANA Cloud offers its own DMS capabilities, which are outside the scope of this blog.

 

2. Scenario and Feasible Option

In our scenario, DMS documents are linked to ERP vendors in the MDG hub system. When vendors are replicated to target systems via web service, the document links are transferred but the actual files are not. Since the systems do not share a common DMS server, users in the target system receive document references that point to files they cannot access.

Two fundamental gaps prevent standard functionality from addressing this requirement: no web service-oriented document replication method exists, and file content cannot be transferred between separate content servers. A custom solution is required. The proposed approach consists of three steps:

  1. Read document links from the source system: Query the DRAD table to identify all DMS documents linked to the vendor being replicated.
  2. Download files from the source system: Use API_CV_ATTACHMENT_SRV to retrieve the actual file content for each linked document.
  3. Create documents in the target system: Use API_DMS_PROCESS_SRV to create the Document Info Record and API_CV_ATTACHMENT_SRV to upload the file content. Then establish the object link to the replicated vendor.

This approach runs within the MDG outbound processing framework, ensuring that document replication is triggered automatically whenever a vendor is replicated via web services.

 

3. Technical Implementation

3.a Architecture Overview


Figure 1: DMS Document replication architecture overview

3.b Service Activation and Connection Setup

Before implementing the replication logic, the required OData services must be activated and the HTTP connections must be configured.

Service Activation

OData services must be activated in both systems via t-code /IWFND/MAINT_SERVICE:

  • API_CV_ATTACHMENT_SRV â€“ API for Attachment Service
  • API_DMS_PROCESS_SRV â€“ API for DMS

SM59 HTTP Destinations

In the source system, two HTTP destinations must be created in transaction SM59 to connect to the target system. Both destinations use connection type H (HTTP Connection to ABAP System).

Z_MER_DMS â€“ Points to the API_DMS_PROCESS_SRV service. This destination is used for creating Document Info Records and establishing object links to the supplier.
Z_MER_DOCUMENT â€“ Points to the API_CV_ATTACHMENT_SRV service. This destination is used for uploading file content to the DIR in the target system.


Figure 2: Configuration for Z_MER_DMS destination
Figure 3: Configuration for Z_MER_DOCUMENT

Both destinations should be configured with appropriate authentication credentials for the target system.

3.c Class Structure

The replication logic is encapsulated in a custom class. This class is initialized with a configuration structure and provides a single public method EXECUTE to trigger the replication process. Internally, the class handles reading document links, downloading files, and creating documents in the target system through private methods.


Figure 4: Replication class methods

The constructor accepts a configuration structure that controls the replication behavior:

TYPES: 
  BEGIN OF ty_config,
    source_supplier   TYPE lifnr, "Supplier number in source system
    target_supplier   TYPE lifnr, "Supplier number in target system
    target_doc_type   TYPE dokar, "Document type to be used in target system
    storage_category  TYPE string, "Content server storage category
    cv_destination    TYPE c LENGTH 20, "Destination name for attachment API
    dms_destination   TYPE c LENGTH 20, "Destination name for DMS API
  END OF ty_config.

 

3.d Read Document Links

The first step identifies all DMS documents linked to the supplier being replicated. This information is stored in the DRAD table, which maintains object links between DIR and business objects.

SELECT DISTINCT dokar, doknr, dokvr, doktl
  FROM drad
  INTO CORRESPONDING FIELDS OF TABLE _document_keys
  WHERE objky = _supplier AND dokob = 'LFA1'.

 

3.e Download Files via OData

Once the document links are identified, the actual files are downloaded from the source system using API_CV_ATTACHMENT_SRV. This process involves two calls: first to retrieve attachment metadata, then to download the binary content.

CSRF Token Handling

Before making any OData calls, a CSRF token must be fetched:

lv_url = gc_cv_service_path && '/$metadata'.

cl_http_utility=>set_request_uri( request = lo_http_client->request  uri = lv_url ).

lo_http_client->request->set_header_field( name = 'x-csrf-token' value = 'Fetch' ).
lo_http_client->request->set_method( 'GET' ).

lo_http_client->send( ).
lo_http_client->receive( ).

lv_csrf_token = lo_http_client->response->get_header_field( 'x-csrf-token' ).

Retrieving Attachment Metadata

For each DIR key, the attachment metadata is retrieved through the navigation property:

lv_url = gc_cv_service_path &&
         |/A_DocumentInfoRecordAttch(| &&
         |DocumentInfoRecordDocType='{ ls_dir_key-dokar }',| &&
         |DocumentInfoRecordDocNumber='{ ls_dir_key-doknr }',| &&
         |DocumentInfoRecordDocVersion='{ ls_dir_key-dokvr }',| &&
         |DocumentInfoRecordDocPart='{ ls_dir_key-doktl }')
         /DocumentInfoRecordToAttachmentNavigation|.

This returns metadata including LogicalDocument, ArchiveDocID, Filename, and MimeType.

Downloading Binary Content

The actual file content is downloaded using the $value endpoint:

lv_url = gc_cv_service_path &&
         |/AttachmentContentSet(| &&
         |DocumentInfoRecordDocType='{ is_nav-documentinforecorddoctype }',| &&
         |DocumentInfoRecordDocNumber='{ is_nav-documentinforecorddocnumber }',| &&
         |LogicalDocument='{ is_nav-logicaldocument }',| &&
         |ArchiveDocumentID='{ is_nav-archivedocumentid }',| &&
         |...)/$value|.

lo_http_client->send( ).
lo_http_client->receive( ).

rs_file-content = lo_http_client->response->get_data( ).  " Returns xstring

The get_data( ) method returns the binary content as xstring.

3.f Create Document in Target System

Creating a document in the target system involves three sub-steps: creating the Document Info Record, establishing the object link to the supplier, and uploading the file content.

DIR Creation

First, a new Document Info Record is created via API_DMS_PROCESS_SRV:

lv_url = '/A_DocumentInfoRecord'.
lv_json = |\{| &&  |"DocumentInfoRecordDocType":"{ ms_config-target_doc_type }",| &&
          |"DocumentInfoRecordDocVersion":"00",| &&
          |"DocumentInfoRecordDocPart":"000"| &&  |\}|.

io_dms_client->request->set_method( 'POST' ).
io_dms_client->request->set_header_field( name = 'x-csrf-token' value = iv_csrf_token ).
io_dms_client->request->set_header_field( name = 'Content-Type' value = 'application/json' ).
io_dms_client->request->set_cdata( lv_json ).

Object Link Creation

After the DIR is created, the link to the supplier is established via the to_ProductObj navigation property:

lv_url = |/A_DocumentInfoRecord(| &&
         |DocumentInfoRecordDocType='{ is_dir_key-dokar }',| &&
         |DocumentInfoRecordDocNumber='{ is_dir_key-doknr }',| &&
         |DocumentInfoRecordDocVersion='{ is_dir_key-dokvr }',| &&
         |DocumentInfoRecordDocPart='{ is_dir_key-doktl }'/to_ProductObj|.

lv_json = |\{| && |"LinkedSAPObject":"LFA1",| &&
          |"LinkedSAPObjectKey":"{ lv_supplier }"| &&  |\}|.

File Upload

Finally, the file content is uploaded via API_CV_ATTACHMENT_SRV. The filename is passed in the header and the binary content is sent in the request body:

lv_url = |/A_DocumentInfoRecordAttch(| &&
         |DocumentInfoRecordDocType='{ is_dir_key-dokar }',| &&
         |DocumentInfoRecordDocNumber='{ is_dir_key-doknr }',| &&
         |DocumentInfoRecordDocVersion='{ is_dir_key-dokvr }',| &&
         |DocumentInfoRecordDocPart='{ is_dir_key-doktl }')
         /DocumentInfoRecordToAttachmentNavigation|.

io_cv_client->request->set_method( 'POST' ).
io_cv_client->request->set_header_field( name = 'x-csrf-token' value = iv_csrf_token ).
io_cv_client->request->set_header_field( name = 'Content-Type' 
                                  value = 'application/octet-stream' ).
io_cv_client->request->set_header_field( name = 'Slug' value = is_file-filename ).
io_cv_client->request->set_header_field( name = 'StorageCategory' 
                                         value = ms_config-storage_category ).
io_cv_client->request->set_data( is_file-content ).

 

3.g Hook into MDG Outbound Processing

To trigger document replication automatically during Business Partner replication, we implement the IF_MDG_SE_BP_BULK_REPLRQ_OUT interface.

METHOD if_mdg_se_bp_bulk_replrq_out~outbound_processing.

  DATA(lv_bp_number) = in-partner-header-object_instance-bpartner.
  
  IF lv_bp_number IS INITIAL.  
   RETURN.  
  ENDIF.

  DATA(lo_replicator) = NEW zcl_dms_doc_replication(
    is_config = VALUE #(
      source_supplier  = lv_bp_number
      target_supplier  = lv_bp_number  "Generally same with source supplier number
      cv_destination   = 'Z_MER_DOCUMENT'
      dms_destination  = 'Z_MER_DMS'
      target_doc_type  = 'KPR'
      storage_category = 'DMS_C1_ST' ) ).

  TRY.
      DATA(ls_result) = lo_replicator->execute( ).
    CATCH cx_static_check INTO DATA(lx_error).
      " Handle error
  ENDTRY.

ENDMETHOD.

This ensures that whenever a supplier is replicated through the standard MDG replication process, the associated DMS documents are replicated automatically.

 

4. Conclusion

In web service-based SAP MDG scenarios, replicating Business Partner master data without its associated DMS documents leads to incomplete and confusing results for end users. This blog demonstrated a practical and reusable approach to closing this gap by leveraging standard OData APIs and integrating the logic directly into the MDG outbound processing framework. By this logic, DMS documents can be replicated automatically whenever a supplier is replicated.

The same concept can be extended to other business objects, such as customers or materials, that use DMS attachments. Until SAP delivers a web serviceâ€“based document replication solution integrated with DRF, this approach provides a robust alternative for MDG implementations that require consistent document availability across systems.

 

Thank you for reading.
Best regards,

Merve

entry.title: Re: How can I run a standard cost estimate for a splitâ€‘va...
entry.content:
Hi Seonjoong,

I did not understand your concern of Different COGS for Domestic  and Foreign sales. SPlit valuation is used for different procurement types like Domestic / Foreign; Inhouse/Purchase etc. Is you customer procuring same Product from Domestic Vendors and Foreign Vendors  and you want to maintain different costs for Domestic and Foreign??

If yes, then you create Split valuation as Domestic and Foreign. At header level the valuation  will be V for the Product. At each split valuation level, you have option to value at S or V.  Since you are procuring from Domestic or Foreign source, you don't need to run the standard cost estimate. You have to maintain separate material prices for Domestic and Foreign Split Valuation type in Fiori App - Manage Material Valuations. System will automatically update value at header level.

entry.title: Re: Project Cost Report does not display actual costs?
entry.content: This usually comes down to how the project is categorized and which cost types the F2513 app is designed to show. The Project Cost Report only picks up costs that are relevant for project cost controlling (for example, assigned to the right project profile, cost elements, and posting categories). If costs are visible in line items but not here, check that the WBS is marked as cost-relevant, the project is released, and that the costs were posted to primary cost elements supported by the app. Also worth double-checking reporting filters like fiscal year/version and that the project is included in the controlling area used by F2513.

entry.title: Think You Know Enterprise Architecture? These 5 Insights Will Change Your Mind
entry.content:
Introduction: Beyond the Blueprint

Enterprise Architecture (EA) is often viewed as a purely technical discipline, bogged down in complex diagrams, rigid governance, and IT-centric rules. This perception paints a picture of EA as a restrictive function that slows down innovation rather than enabling it.

However, this view misses the true purpose of modern EA. The core principles of the SAP Enterprise Architecture Framework reveal a discipline that is dynamic, flexible, and fundamentally a strategic tool for business. Here are five surprising truths that reframe Enterprise Architecture not as a technical constraint, but as an essential driver of business value and transformation.

It's Fundamentally About Business Strategy, Not IT Policing

The primary role of Enterprise Architecture is to solve a critical business problem: the misalignment between business strategy and IT execution. In the past, technology often evolved separately from business strategy, leading to wasted resources and missed opportunities. Enterprise Architecture was developed to correct this. Just as a buildingâ€™s blueprint ensures all components work together to create a functional structure, EA provides the blueprint for aligning business and IT toward a common goal.

Effective EA fosters this alignment to drive specific business outcomes, including:

  • Better operational excellence
  • More customer intimacy
  • Greater product leadership
  • More strategic agility

This shift in perspective is crucial. It positions EA as a value-driver focused on maximizing the ROI of technology investments and enabling strategic goals, rather than as a restrictive governance function that simply polices IT standards.

There Is No "One-Size-Fits-All" Team Structure

Contrary to the idea of a single, rigid EA office, there is no one correct way to structure an Enterprise Architecture practice. An organization can adopt the EA model that best fits its specific culture, maturity, and business structure. The SAP framework identifies four distinct organizational models:

  • Informal: EA skills are integrated into other roles without a dedicated team.
  • Separated: Each organizational unit operates its own local EA function.
  • Federated/Distributed: Local EAs from each unit form a virtual, collaborative team.
  • Centralized: A single, central EA team is responsible for the entire organization.

This flexibility is a significant strategic advantage. It allows a company with loosely coupled divisions to adopt a federated model, keeping architects close to the business functions they support while the federated structure helps avoid redundant work and architectural conflicts. Conversely, an organization with strong corporate functions might benefit from a centralized approach. The goal is to choose the structure that most effectively embeds architectural thinking into the business.

A Good Framework is a Guide, Not a Cage

The SAP Enterprise Architecture Methodology is not a rigid set of rules but a tailored adaptation of the industry-standard TOGAF framework, designed for flexibility. The process is highly iterative and is not intended to be a linear, waterfall-based approach. Architects are encouraged to iterate within phases, between phases, and in response to stakeholder feedback.

The core philosophy is that the work must always serve the business and its stakeholders. This principle is captured perfectly in the framework's guidance on selecting which architectural artifacts to create for a project:

These should be selected for the sake of the stakeholders (not for the sake of architecture)

This focus on practical value over procedural purity ensures that the EA process remains a helpful guide for achieving business outcomes, not a bureaucratic cage that stifles progress.

You Don't Start with a Blank Page

A key component of the SAP EA Framework is "Reference Architecture Content," which gives architects a significant head start on their work. Instead of creating architectural models from scratch, they are provided with pre-built, high-quality content, including standardized business capability and process models based on industry standards like the APQC Cross-Industry Process Classification Framework.

The impact of this approach goes far beyond simple acceleration. By providing a shared, business-centric vocabulary, this content creates a traceable line from strategy to execution. Having business and IT perspectives closely interlinked allows for seamless navigation from high-level business capabilities all the way down to the specific SAP products and technical implementation artifacts that bring them to life. This ensures business and IT are aligned from day one.

Modern EA is a Complete Ecosystem, Not Just a Process

A mature Enterprise Architecture approach is far more than just a methodology document; it is a complete support system for business transformation. The SAP Enterprise Architecture Framework is built on five core building blocks that work together to create a holistic ecosystem:

  1. Methodology: A proven methodology adapted from the TOGAF industry standard to guide architecture development.
  2. Reference Architecture Content: Pre-built business and solution models that accelerate projects and ensure alignment.
  3. Tooling: An integrated set of tools like SAP Signavio and LeanIX to support the creation, management, and consumption of EA content.
  4. Practice: The organizational operating model and governance structure that embeds EA within the business.
  5. Services: Standardized expert services to support customer transformation programs when needed.

These components create a synergistic support system where each element addresses a critical need. The Methodology provides the how, the Content provides the what, the Tooling provides the efficiency, the Practice provides the organizational home, and the Services provide the expert guidance.

Conclusion: What Does Your Blueprint Look Like?

Modern Enterprise Architecture, when viewed through a strategic lens, is a flexible, accessible, and business-focused discipline. It moves beyond rigid technical blueprints to become a dynamic guide for aligning technology with business goals, accelerating transformation, and maximizing value.

Considering these five insights, which shift in perspective could unlock the most value for your organization?

entry.title: Digital Transformation. View of an Enterprise Architect - Conway's Law
entry.content:
â€ƒ #GenerativeArt

 

Out of the Ivory Tower: Architecture, Organization, and the Reality of SAP Transformations

Many SAP transformations today do not fail because of technology. SAP S/4HANA, cloud architectures, and modern integration platforms are mature and powerful. Yet in practice, end-to-end processes often remain slow and inefficient.

The root cause is frequently not the system itself, but the organization that designs, operates, and evolves it.

 

When SAP Architecture Meets Organizational Silos

In many enterprises, SAP organizations have historically been structured around technical modules such as SD, MM, or FI. While these modules are technically connected through document flows, they are often organizationally separated.

This leads to familiar challenges:

  • High coordination effort across team boundaries.

  • Fragmented ownership along end-to-end processes.

  • Long lead times despite modern platforms.

As we discussed in Part 2 of this series, breaking down these organizational silos is one of the critical success factors for any digital transformation project. Without addressing these structural barriers, even the most advanced SAP S/4HANA migration or BTP implementation will struggle to deliver its full business value.

As a result, architecture becomes a reflection of organizational reality rather than a driver of innovation. If the organization thinks in silos, the system will operate in silosâ€”regardless of the technology used.

 

Conwayâ€™s Law: Relevant in Everyday Practice

This pattern can be explained by Conwayâ€™s Law:
Systems inevitably mirror the communication and decision structures of the organizations that design them.

For SAP customers, this means that as long as organizations are aligned around technical components, architectures will follow the same structureâ€”regardless of how advanced the underlying technology is. Agile methods alone do not change this as long as structural dependencies remain.

 

A Realistic Perspective on Organizational Change

Especially in large, established SAP organizations, one thing is clear:
Breaking down organizational silos is difficult and often not fully achievable.

Governance models, reporting lines, and historically grown responsibilities impose real constraints. A radical organizational redesign is therefore rarely feasible in the short term.

 

Why Awareness Still Makes a Difference

The key benefit already starts with awareness of the relationship between organization and architecture:

  • dependencies become visible earlier
  • architectural decisions are assessed more realistically
  • interfaces are understood as organizational, not just technical, challenges

Even without major reorganization, this awareness enables targeted improvementsâ€”for example, clearer end-to-end ownership for critical initiatives or more deliberate team setups where it matters most.

 

Conclusion

SAP architecture does not emerge in an ivory tower. It is always shaped by the organizational context in which it is created.
Those who understand and consider Conwayâ€™s Law make better architectural decisionsâ€”even when organizational silos cannot be fully removed.

Architecture is organizational design.

 

What Does This Mean for Your SAP Transformation?

Taking a conscious look at organizational structures, responsibilities, and communication paths can significantly improve the effectiveness of architectural decisions. Not every organization needs to be redesignedâ€”but every transformation benefits from thinking about architecture and organization together.

 

Common thread of this blog series:

  1. Introduction 
  2. Tasks of an Enterprise Architect 
  3. Success Factors for Digital Transformation Projects 
  4. Help of an Enterprise-Architecture-Framework 
  5. Steps and Tips 
  6. Artificial Intelligence Meets Enterprise Architecture
  7. Conwayâ€™s Law

 

 

Reference:

Hohmann, M.; Wagner, D.: Architecture Is Organizational Design, iX â€“ Magazine for Professional Information Technology, Issue 1/2026.

entry.title: Re: Implementing a RHEL HA Add-On Cluster with SBD fencing for SAP Solutions on IBM Power10 Servers
entry.content:
Hello Charles,
the SBD setup depends on your storage configuration. Red Hat provides detailed recommendations in this article: https://access.redhat.com/articles/2941601.

The general guideline is to use one or three SBD devices:

  • If all storage for both sites comes from the same shared storage subsystem, use one SBD device, as additional devices would not increase redundancy.
  • If your storage comes from independent storage subsystems (for example, host-based mirroring or SAP HANA System Replication with separate storage), use three devices:
    • One from each storage subsystem
    • A third from another site, such as an iSCSI device

SBD fencing (poison-pill via block device) is designed to prevent split-brain scenarios.
However, in the event of a complete network outage affecting both IP and storage, additional measures such as a third-site quorum or witness can further reduce risk. Mixing SBD with a third-site witness is possible.

For additional information, see our SAP High Availability documentation series on IBM Cloud. Although these resources focus on deployments in IBM PowerVS, much of the content is applicable to on-premises environments as well. In particular, the section â€œImplementing SBD poison-pill fencing in a Red Hat Enterprise Linux High Availability Add-On clusterâ€ provides an example configuration using three iSCSI devices hosted in different zones.
 
Hope this helps,
Walter

entry.title: Re: Do client computers need to have SQL Anywhere install...
entry.content:
Please check the following.

  • Ensure that the SQL Anywhere running is a network server (dbsrv17)
  • Ensure that you can ping the host where SQL Anywhere server is running at the client , 
  • Determine the database engine (server) name and the database name  -- values in the <...> depend on your specific configuration.
    • dbsrv17 -n <ServerName>  database.db -n <DatabaseName>
  • In the client connect, supply the Host,  Server, and DatabaseName connection parameters. For the example above 
    • HOST=<host_machine_name_or_ip>:2638;ServeNamer=<ServerName>;DatabaseName=<DatabaseName>

This is useful guide if you are unsure of how the server and database names are determined. How the SQL Anywhere Server and Database Get Their Names.. Alternatively, you can execute the following to assist in identify key elements for a connection to a SQL Anywhere server - this should be run from the machine where you can connect.

select
    property('Name') as ServerName
    , db_property('Name') as DatabaseName
    , property('MachineName') as HostMachineName
    , property( 'TcpIpListeners') as TCPIPListener;

The TCPIPListener should include the IP and port number that the listeners are enabled.  There may be multiple listeners enabled ( for example, an IPv4 and an IPv6 based IP address).

  2. Designing data products that preserve business context across SAP and non-SAP sources
  3. Governance-by-design, including data quality, lineage, and access control
  4. How BDC Connect enables a true open ecosystem with zero-copy architecture
  5. What â€œAI-readyâ€ really means from an architectural perspective

The message is clear: the data architecture decisions you make today will shape your organizationâ€™s ability to compete and innovate for the next decade.

Add to calendar: https://community.sap.com/khhcw49343/downloadCalendar?message.id=14304242

 

Session 7: Design. Govern. Deliver. Data Products with SAP Data Product Studio

We pause for 3 weeks with a hands-on look at SAP Data Product Studio, a new capability in SAP Business Data Cloud, before diving into the important topic of licensing on April 16.

In this session, youâ€™ll see how teams can:

  • Build, manage, and govern data products at scale
  • Use a visual workspace to model and enrich data across SAP and third-party sources
  • Leverage metadata, lineage, SQL-based transformations, and versioning
  • Govern data products through a shared domain catalog

The focus is on bringing structure to the full data product lifecycle while enabling faster innovation without sacrificing trust or consistency.

Add to calendar: https://community.sap.com/khhcw49343/downloadCalendar?message.id=14294191

 

Join the Series, register here: https://events.sap.com/data-analytics/en_us/home.html

This live YouTube series is designed to help our community make sense of where enterprise data is heading and how to act on it today.

If you care about trusted data, scalable analytics, open ecosystems, and architecting for AI, this series is for you.

Stay tuned for updates, and get ready to discover SAP Business Data Cloud in 2026.

entry.title: Re: Table T169TM: entry does not exist
entry.content:
Good day @jerrysam 

Thank you for your question

The error you mentioned is not a random backend dump. That error usually indicates that the invoice posting is triggering a logic in your Transportation Management but the integration settings in your TM integration are not fully available or not consistent for your scenario.  T169TM is used for TM integration settings.

So, in public cloud, you cannot correct that situation by maintaining tables in the background. You can either:

  • Adjust your scope and configuration (SSCUIs and CBC) or
  • You raise an incident if your configuration is already correct but the system still calls TM logic incorrectly.

In public cloud, you have the possibility to validate to validate whether your PO and supplier invoice are being processed as TM relevant and correct the setup using CBC. See https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0fa84c9d9c634132b7c4abb9ffdd8f06/5485fb2fbc7e488c8b85b22ee754c7d9.html for more details.

The most like root causes to check in your system are:

  • Your currency type (basically currency settings) is referenced by the posting logic but it is not present in the defined currency settings you have defined.
  • Considering the public cloud provides only one fixed controlling area, if something expects object currency handling but your setup is inconsistent, then you can see currency issued when you post. See https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/6b39bd1d0e5e4099a5b65d835c29c696/60bbd07a3b29421bbe3b87c0e1d9cfd6.html for more details.
  • Posting apps such as supplier invoice posting and reversal can trigger KM133 if your currency and valuation type configuration is not consistent. See KBA 3126387 for some insights.

A potential reason why that error appears during Supplier Invoice, is when the referenced purchase order is TM relevant or has a TM related status and your invoice verification tries to apply TM reference processing. KBA 3418733 and 2866486 provide some details.

You should check as a first option if the PO is TM related, your invoice app may show TM reference behaviour or the PO may carry TM status fields depending on your scope and UI.

To summarise:

  1. The error usually points to TM integration being triggered during invoice verification
  2. The public cloud provides a fix through CBC scope and configuration. Not for the customer to correct it through the backend.
  3. If your configuration is incorrect, consider raising an incident with some details.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Variant Configuration â€“ Subassembly BOM items with selection conditions not exploding in CU51
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

I am struggling with a variant configuration issue in a multiâ€‘level BOM and would really appreciate some guidance.

I have created a configurable material with a characteristic ZS5_LT that represents the length of a ladder.
In the BOM of this configurable material, I have several ladder components, each with a selection condition, for example:

  • 4.4 m ladder: selection condition ZS5_LT = 4.4
  • other ladders with similar conditions, depending on the value of ZS5_LT.

When I test this material in transaction CU50, everything works as expected:
If I set ZS5_LT = 4.4, the 4.4 m ladder is selected correctly in the result.

However, my problem occurs when I use this configurable material as a subassembly in another assembly.

Scenario:

  • The configurable material is inserted as a component in a higherâ€‘level assembly in the BOM.
  • In CSKB / CU51, I select the configurable subassembly, enter the configuration there, and set ZS5_LT = 4.4 m.
  • Then I press â€œResultâ€ or go back to the BOM view and expect to see the 4.4 m ladder under the configurable subassembly.

What actually happens:

  • No ladder is selected at all under the configurable subassembly when the selection condition is active.
  • If I remove the selection condition from the 4.4 m ladder item in the BOM, the ladder appears in CU51 as a static component.
  • So the BOM explosion for the subassembly works, but the selection condition based on ZS5_LT is not evaluated as I expect in the order BOM context.

My understanding is that this might be related to multiâ€‘level configuration and how characteristics are evaluated at different levels (parent vs. subassembly). It looks like the system is looking for the characteristic higher up in the structure, but the characteristic is only defined and used for the configurable material.

Any hints, best practices, or example setups for this kind of multiâ€‘level configuration with a configurable subassembly in CU51 would be very helpful.

Thank you in advance!

entry.title: Using Different ATP Checking Rules for Planned Orders and Process Orders in SAP S/4HANA PP
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

I am working on SAP S/4HANA (Standard) in Production Planning â€“ Process Industry (PP-PI) and I have the following two requirements related to Availability Check:

  1. Planned Orders (after MRP run):
    Once MRP is executed and planned orders are generated, I want to run an availability check to verify whether the required components are available in the plant, in order to validate the feasibility of planned orders before conversion.

  2. Process Orders (after conversion):
    After converting the planned order to a process order, I want to run another availability check to verify whether the components have already been staged / transferred to the production storage location.

From my understanding:

  • In MRP Customizing (OPPQ), the checking rule for ATP in planned orders is assigned (default = PP).

  • In OPJK, the checking rule for process orders is also assigned (default = PP).

  • Regardless of the checking rule, the components are still assigned to a single Availability Check Control (e.g. 02 / CH) at material level.

This leads me to the following questions:

  • Is it acceptable / recommended to separate the checking rules for planned orders and process orders (e.g. PP for process orders and a custom rule like PP2 for planned orders)?

  • Is there a standard SAP checking rule intended for this scenario, or is creating a custom rule the correct approach?

  • How do you typically differentiate between:

    • a feasibility check at planned order level, and

    • a staging/transfer validation at process order level,
      given that the same availability check control is used?

My goal is:

  • To use availability check on planned orders to validate feasibility before conversion.

  • To use availability check on process orders to confirm whether material staging has been completed.

Any guidance on best practice or standard SAP behavior would be highly appreciated.

Thank you in advance.

entry.title: Re: ABAP Extensibility Guide â€“ Clean Core for SAP S/4HANA Cloud - August 2025 Update
entry.content:
Hi @OlgaDolinskaja ,

I came across this blog of you when looking for some proof to indicate that SQV* queries are not considered clean core.
So far I found nothing clearly stating that this is the case, even though I am fully aware that the use of those queries is far from clean core simply because they use tables directly and generate classic programs, both of these are not considered clean core.

As alternatives I can think of the following options:

1. Using Standard Apps or Reports
Using standard objects is always preferred. 

2. Custom CDS Views App
https://fioriappslibrary.hana.ondemand.com/sap/fix/externalViewer/#/detail/Apps('F1866A')/S31PCE 
This allows for the creation of CDS views without writing code, though some limitations apply.
The most significant limitation is likely that only released views can be used; however, this immediately ensures the solution is Cloud Ready.

3. Building a Custom (RAP-based) CDS Report
This option removes the restrictions found in the first two options.
The developer can create a report exactly as requested.
Development must still adhere to best practices and guidelines.

I would love to get your insights and ideas on this.
Thanks a lot.

Kind Regards,
Joery

entry.title: The Secret Shopper for SAP Agents: Why Enterprise AI Needs a Reality Check with Int4 Suite
entry.content:
The enterprise software world is currently â€œa bitâ€ obsessed with "Agentic AI". Weâ€™re moving away from rigid, click-here-then-there workflows toward SAP Joule agents, autonomous entities that can reason, use tools, and execute complex business processes like the ones show in the figure below: 

Figure 1 - SAP Joule Agents 

But as we hand the keys of our SAP S/4HANA systems over to these digital coworkers, we face a fundamental crisis: The Death of Determinism. For decades, software testing followed a simple rule: Input X + Logic F = Output Y. It was predictable. With AI agents, thatâ€™s gone. An agent might solve the same problem three different ways on three different days. This creates a "Verification Gap" where traditional testing fails. If your AI agent "hallucinates" a successful transaction that never actually hits the database, your supply chain doesn't just slow down, it breaks. Here is why your enterprise needs a new way to test, and how Int4 Suite is stepping in as an Enterprise AI validator or in some business scenarios as a "Secret Shopper" for the AI era.

The Hallucination Trap: Why "Polite" AI Isn't Enough for Enterprise AI 

Most AI testing tools today are Guardrail Platforms. They are like bouncers at a club: they make sure the AI doesn't say anything offensive, leak a credit card number, or succumb to a prompt injection attack.

While essential for security, these tools have a massive blind spot: Functional Integrity. If SAP Joule Agents tells you, "Iâ€™ve processed that sales order for you!" with a polite digital smile, but it actually failed to map the tax jurisdiction code correctly in SAP S/4HANA, the "security" tools won't catch it. They validate the Tool Call (what the agent intended to do), but they don't validate the Tool Execution (what actually happened in the database).

The "Secret Shopper" Scenario: Order-to-Cash

Imagine you want to check the quality of service at a high-end retail store. You don't just ask the manager if the staff is good; you send in a Secret Shopper, a person with a specific script who tests the system's limits and reports back on exactly what happened.

In the world of SAP S/4HANA, Int4 Suite acts as that Secret Shopper for the Order-to-Cash (O2C) process. Hereâ€™s how the "Mission" looks:

  1. The Trigger: A customer sends an email with an attached PDF order.

  2. The Agent's Job: SAP Joule (the AI agent) must read the email, parse the PDF, and autonomously create a Sales Order, an Outbound Delivery, and an Invoice in SAP S/4HANA.

Figure 2 - Order to Cash process started by a PDF inside an e-mail, processed by the AI Agent completely 

  1. The Int4 Suite "Mission":

  • Fetch & Fabricate: Int4 Suite fetches a real historical email and PDF from your system using its Robotic Crawler. It then dynamically changes the values (unique qualifier like the Order reference, etc.) so the test is unique and won't clash with existing data.

  • The Sting: Int4 Suite resends this unique "mystery" order to the AI agent.

  • The Deep Audit: This is where Int4 Suite shines. While other tools just watch the "chat," Int4 Suite goes into the SAP S/4HANA backend. It validates the resulting documents up to the field level.

Figure 3 - Replication of the original process by this time completely run by Int4 Suite and validated in the SAP S/4HANA DB. 

Did the agent correctly calculate the net value? Is the shipping point correct? Did the invoice trigger the right accounting document? Int4 Suite compares the agent's work against historical "gold standard" documents to ensure 100% accuracy.

Figure 4 - SAP S/4HANA DB validation of a sales order posting 

The FWE Model: A New Standard for AI Validation

To truly trust an AI agent, you need a Functional Workflow Execution (FWE) model. This is the architectural loop that Int4 Suite has perfected:

  • Technical Flow Implementation: Setting up the "harness" where the agent lives.

  • Test Case Definition: Defining what "success" actually looks like - Order posted with a certain number of lines, Delivery posted with certain quantities, etc..

Figure 5 - Test Workflow definition inside Int4 Suite 

  • Dynamic Data Fabrication: Using the Robotic Crawler to mine historical messages and "seed" the test environment with valid, complex data.

  • Agent Execution: Letting the AI run wild in a deterministic "sandbox."

  • Backend Validation: Programmatically inspecting SAP S/4HANA database entries, IDocs, and API responses to verify the "side effects" of the AIâ€™s actions.

Why Int4 Suiteâ€™s approach is Unique? 

While the market is flooded with "AI Security" startups, they lack the "plumbing" to talk to SAP. Int4 Suite was born in the world of SAP integration (PI/PO, CPI). It speaks the language of IDocs, OData, APIs in general.

We are witnessing a shift from deterministic chains to probabilistic agents. You can't test a probabilistic agent with a spreadsheet and a prayer.

If you are deploying SAP Joule, you need a validator that doesn't just listen to what the agent says, but verifies what the agent did. By leveraging service virtualization and deep backend inspection, Int4 Suite ensures that your "Secret Shopper" tests don't just find hallucinations, they build a foundation of enterprise-grade trust.

Ready to send a Secret Shopper into your S/4HANA system? Itâ€™s time to move beyond the chat bubble and into the database.

Further Learning on Int4 Suite: Avoiding Project Delays

If you want to dive deeper into how to decouple your project timeline from external risks, SAP provides a dedicated learning path on this exact topic.

  • SAP Learning Course: Avoid SAP S/4HANA Project Delays with Third-Party Systems Service Virtualization

entry.title: Re: Packaging Instruction Determination Not Triggering Di...
entry.content:
Hello @vicentejarque

Thank you for your question

What you configured in Maintain Packing Transaction Profile is valid configuration but the behaviour you expect typically does not appear in the Fiori process. The reason is that the packing execution in these apps is based on Unified Package Building and in that framework the Packing Instruction Selection Dialog parameter is not evaluated.  See Unified Package Building Profile for more details.

That is why you see automatic determination but no user choice dialog, even when alternative packing instructions exist.

Important consideration to note, VL31N is an SAP GUI transaction. The public cloud expects you to use the Fiori inbound delivery apps. The relevant packing execution is the packing work center launched from Change Inbound Deliveries. Your observation in the Fiori app is the one that matters for public cloud behaviour.

In public cloud it is possible to use packing instruction determination to automatically create HU proposals, use alternative packing instructions but only as part of automatic logic and maintain records with the condition technique so the system selects the correct packing instruction. See Packing Instruction Determination and HUM - Determination record for packing instruction for more insights.

However, you cannot manually select dialog for choosing between multiple valid packing instructions during automatic expansion. The selection dialog setting in the packing transaction profile is not taken into account in UPB based packing.

So, you are not missing an SSCUI step. It seems you are facing a functional public cloud limitation of the packing execution framework. So, the question is, how do you model two valid options without relying on a user dialog.

My suggestion is to make the determination unambiguous. If the material can arrive in two different forms, you should make that difference explicit in your determination criteria so only one packing instruction is valid at a time. The public cloud offers you the options to:

  1. Use different determination keys based on business data that is available at inbound delivery level for example supplier, plant, ship to part, etc.
  2. If the difference is truly physical form A versus form B, you should consider using batch characteristics or a distinguishable product attribute that is available at the time of receipt, then you drive the determination with that.

Another option, if you truly need a warehouse operator choice when you execute, that requirement is more aligned with the EWM packaging specification handling than S4 packing instruction selection dialog expectations. In public cloud embedded EWM, many packing activities are executed in EWM style apps but the specific selection dialog flag you referenced is not the mechanism to achieve that in Fiori.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: How to Identify Source Tables and Fields for Legal Parameters in SAP HR Payroll
entry.content:
Hello,

As you know, there are many SAP standard tables where rates and parameters are maintained for payroll calculations. These values are later used in payroll schemas and rules to produce payroll results.

When a legal parameter changes, I would like to understand how I can identify from which table and which specific field the system is reading the data.
For example, tables such as T7TRG01, V_T7TRG02, V_T7TRT01, V_T7TRT02, V_T7TRT03, and similar ones.

My usual approach is to start from a wage type generated for a specific personnel number and then trace it backwards. During this process, I often end up at table T596F, but at that point I still cannot clearly identify which field or logic is used to calculate the wage type.

Is there an easier or more systematic way to analyze this?
If you have any known methods, best practices, or tips for tracing payroll calculations back to their source tables and fields, I would really appreciate your guidance.

Thank you in advance for your support.

Best regards,
Enes

entry.title: Integrating Cloud Application Lifecyle Management (CALM) with Trading Partner Management (TPM)
entry.content:
Introduction

I am happy to announce that SAP Cloud ALM can now be connected to Trading Partner Management, with which you can configure automated alerting based on B2B scenario-specific details, like trading partners, type systems, message types, etc.
Building a seamless End-To-End monitoring experience closes the gap between IT and business. 
In this blog, we explore how unifying CALM and TPM streamlines operations and helps teams detect issues earlier - before they impact critical business processes. 

The integration between SAP Cloud ALM and SAP Cloud services like SAP Integration Suite (Trading Partner Management) is orchestrated by SAP-Managed Connectivity, which already provides an automated connectivity setup for all your tenants.
All you need to do is to activate the TPM integration, so that the data is sent from TPM to CALM.
In addition, you need to turn on the data collection, so that CALM continuously (every 5 minutes) pulls data (every interchange) from TPM's B2B Monitoring. This is a one-time activity.
*In CALM it is called the push job because data is pushed from TPM to CALM.*
The alert notification configurations are done on CALM side.  


Setup steps in SAP Cloud ALM

Activation

Go to CALM --> Operations --> Integration & Exception Monitoring 

*Note: Health Monitoring will not be available in CALM for Trading Partner Management. The certificate alert in the Trading Partner Profiles (TPP) will be implemented within TPM itself. In the TPM UI, you will see which certificates are about to expire soon and are already expired. 

Go to Select a Scope --> Select all relevant Services, particularly SAP Integration Suite (Trading Partner Management) --> Go --> Apply

You will now see the scope based on your settings. 
Go to Configuration --> Services/Systems --> Activate the service

*Note: For the initial enablement, it could take up to 24 hours for the data to start appearing.
Once you see the messages, you are connected to TPM:

Note: In the screenshot above you see the messages from January 12 00:00am to January 12 4:04pm. You can adjust the time frame accordingly. Further you see that in this time frame there is one failed interchange and in total three open alerts that are still to be investigated by operations team (Alerts and E-Mail notification were already maintained in this case). 
You can also click on the Messages Hyperlink to view the messages and see the relevant metadata in detail.
Currently, only failed or unassigned interchanges are marked in red in CALM.

Notification Management

If you plan to automatically trigger alerts via e-mail, you have to maintain the users or distribution lists inside of CALM.

Note: CALM will unify Notification Management with User Management to simplify your tasks. The dedicated management of recipients in Notification Management will soon be deprecated.
Hence, all users in User Management app can receive notifications.
You can create external users or distribution lists as users in the User Management without assigning them any roles.

In the future Go to CALM --> Administration --> User Management

 

As long as it is still not migrated to the new approach
Go to CALM --> Notification Management

Note: Once you have added the recipients, they will receive a notification and must give the consent. Once this is done the status will switch from Pending to Verified. The validity period for users is six months, after which it must be extended.

 Configuration - Event Settings

Now we have to define the parameters for the Event actions. 
Go to Edit Configuration

Go to Events --> Add

*Note: The following will give a proposal on how the configuration could look like.
Choose the Event Name: Issues detected in SAP Trading Partner Management and define the parameter values, so that one event per calculation is sufficient - meaning that if a single interchange is detected, it will be registered as soon as the message is older than 1 minute:

As mentioned in the beginning the most critical interchanges are the failed and unassigned ones. That is why we will filter particularly for them:


Now we need to define the grouping parameters for the event.
Basically, the alerts or the e-mail body will contain the Object Details with all these attributes filled with their values of the corresponding interchange, such as for example Direction = OUTBOUND | Receiver Document Standard = SAP_IDoc | Sender Message Type = 850, etc. 

This is then how an example alert looks like in CALM:

 

Now coming to the last step on how the event action should look like. In this case we do want to see the alerts in CALM and additionally send email to the specific group:

Save the configuration settings and you are done. 
Note: There is also the possibility to connect CALM to external ticket systems, such as ServiceNow to create incidents. There is also the possibility that CALM can forward the exceptions to chat tools, such as MS Teams to create messages in chat channels. 
This is not covered in this blog.

Analysis of E-Mail Alerts

The E-Mail will contain the Object Details shown above (For unassigned interfaces, there won't be any attribute, except for the Message ID) and additional information with the Message ID (each interchange has a unique ID), the Status text, from which you could derive already what kind of issue it is and the timestamp (caution: CALM uses UTC, while B2B Monitoring uses the user's local timezone):

Interchange Transmission Failed always refer to that the target message could not be send to the receiving system, due to e.g. unavailability of the system. 
You can click on the hyperlink to view the alert in CALM. Monitoring in CALM will be shown in the next section.
I want to show how this message can be easily found in B2B Monitoring using the Message ID:

*Note: Once the system is available, you can use the retry mechanism of B2B Monitoring

In the same way, you can search for unassigned messages and view the error details:


Nice to know

Before we jump into the Monitoring in CALM, there is one more additional feature that you should know. It might be the case that the user wants to preferably monitor the interchanges in CALM using unique business document identifiers, such as e.g. the Purchase Order number or the Invoice number.
CALM's Monitoring dashboard supports an additional search field (next to the Message ID), which is the Document ID.
In TPM, we use the same terminology, which needs to be defined as Custom Search Attribute:

Now in each business transaction activity, you can define the value of the Document ID (usually via XPath). 
If you want to log the IDoc Number for messages that are send via IDoc Receiver Adapter, use the Source Type Parameter and the value SAP_TPM_IDocNumber:

This provides complete traceability across the whole process.


Monitoring in SAP Cloud ALM

As you saw in the mail, you can view the alert in CALM. If you click on the hyperlink you will be redirected to CALM's alert dashboard:

You can click on the Message ID and can see further details, such as the B2B Monitoring URL and a more detailed error description:

If you want to see all messages, click on the Messages Hyperlink in the Integration & Exception Monitoring Dashboard:

 

You will see some charts about the total number of messages by e.g. Receiver Name, Sender Name, Sender Message Type, etc. 
You can apply the filter to search for messages based on a unique business document identifier:

 


Share your thoughts

I'd love to hear what you think about the current solution.
Your feedback will help to get further valuable perspectives on how automated alerting could be optimized.

entry.title: Re: BADI/Function Module for Variant Configuration in Sal...
entry.content:
Dear @s_sudhirkumar,

In Private Cloud the Import Sales Orders using Files app (F4293) is backed by the Sales Document Import from Spreadsheet framework and as delivered, it does not reliably support configurable materials / VC. SAP has an explicit Note describing the symptom when you try to import a sales order for a configurable material the sales order item is created without characteristic values or the order is not created at all

SAP Note below:

https://me.sap.com/notes/0003198686

Best-practice recommendation for Private Edition, if you need this to be robust and upgrade-tolerant:

1. Do not enhance the delivered SAPUI5/Fiori app (F4293) directly to handle VC payload. You will be coupling yourself to SAP internal import job structures and upgrade cycles and you still need a backend VC-capable creation interface

2. Build a custom mass-upload service ABAP/RAP or classic that:

    • reads the spreadsheet
    • maps columns to characteristic/value assignments
    • calls BAPI_SALESORDER_CREATEFROMDAT2 with the ORDER_CFGS_* tables filled or sends ORDERS05 if you choose IDoc
    • returns an application log comparable to F4293

More details below:

https://api.sap.com/package/eu10.storecontentdev.creationofsalesorderbapi5/overview

This gives you clean control over:

  • validation mandatory characteristics, allowed values
  • performance batching/commit strategy
  • error handling and replay
  • future VC changes new characteristics, multi-value characteristics

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Error message when trying to access "My Products Packages" for SAP BDC
entry.content:
**Updated January 2026**

Symptom: You see the following message when you go to "Portfolio & Products" section from Dashboards in SAP for Me to get access to the SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) card: "No authorization. You are missing authorizations for your eligible product packages. Make sure that you have either Display Cloud Data or Edit Cloud Data authorization for the installation number of each product package."

Requirements: You need to be a Cloud or Super Admin in SAP for Me. 

Resolution: A) Find out your installation name and number and B) Proceed with the authorization task. 

A) Find out your installation name and number:

1. Open this link ("Business Data Cloud" page in "Portfolio & Products"). 

2. Click on the line "SAP Business Data Cloud". 

3. Go to "Systems" tab and check the second column, "Installation". There is an installation name and number. In this example, the installation name is "SAP Cloud Generic", and the installation number starts with 9.

4. Save this installation name and number for the next step. 

Image 01

Image 02

 

B) Proceed with the authorization task:

1. Open this link ("S-User Management" page from SAP for Me).

2. Search for the user name you want to provide access to.

3. Click on the user line.

4. Go to the "Authorizations" section, then click to edit it.

5. Go to "Cloud" section and check the boxes for both options, "Display Cloud Data" and "Edit Cloud Data".

6. Open the installations and make sure you are assigned to the one related to BDC. In this example, the user doesn't have the installation attached. 

7. Click on the "+" sign.

8. Select the installation name and number from SAP BDC, then click "Ok". 

9. Goo back to the authorizations page, scroll up to the title "Authorizations", and click "Save". 

10. A pop up will appear: "Authorizations were updated successfully". 

 

Image 01

Image 02

Image 03

Image 04

Image 05

Image 06

Image 07

Sources:

  •  About the User, Authorization and Administrator Concept

entry.title: Re: Authorisations of Business Partners Roles
entry.content:
• Do not assign role 000000 to business users.
  • Assign FLN01 and configure field control to restrict financial fields.
  • Use business catalogs to control app access.
  • Restrict BP role maintenance via B_BUPA_RLT.
  • Test with a user having only FLN01 and validate field-level restrictions.
